text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
Hello, this is Sarah Lucas.

I'm here to walk you
through the extracurriculars

and awards and recognitions
sections of our application.

Let's begin with the
extracurricular activities.

We want to build a class of
diverse and authentic leaders.

My advice then, is
to pursue things

that are meaningful
or exciting to you,

do them well, with energy,
and yes, with passion.

You'll learn a lot more,
likely to have more impact,

and probably enjoy
yourself, too.

Many strong applicants have
common extracurriculars,

but they pursue them
with uncommon purpose
or persistence.

We give you space to list three
extracurricular activities,
but don't worry.

If you don't have three to
list, better to have one to two
that are really meaningful.

And yes, totally fine to list
extracurriculars from college,
too.

Now, let's talk about
awards and recognitions.

This section should be
pretty straightforward.

We give you the chance
to list three awards
from any part of your life.

You'll have a small
bit of space to give us

more detail on how you were
chosen for the award or honor.

Again, choose the awards that
are most meaningful to you
personally.

It really can be helpful if
you can take time, but really

think about how to best capture
the award, the recognition,

that basis of selection, and
why it's so meaningful to you.

When you step back from these
sections of the application,

ask yourself if the
things you chose to list

give us a good sense of what's
important to you outside
of work.

Finally, if there are additional
extracurricular activities

or awards that you would like us
to be aware of beyond the three

you can list in these
sections, please
include them on your resume.

For more information, visit
our application process page
and good luck.
